channel.title: Beogram 4002 Type 5513 on 0x000216
channel.description: Recent content in Beogram 4002 Type 5513 on 0x000216

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Service Manual Adjustments & Preparing for Use
item.description: In the previous post, I finished cleaning and deoxidizing the keypad and RPM panel. The keypad is now responsive, but the cueing up and down button is overly sensitive and needs further attention. The RPM panel re-installation was put on hold because the plastic mounting fixtures were cracked, a common issue with Beogram 4002 turntables. I was fortunate that the cracks weren’t severe and the fixtures were still usable. To repair them, I used acrylic repair fluid while pressing the pieces together.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Keypad and RPM Panel
item.description: Slow response times from the Beogram’s control panel buttons pointed to potential oxidation on the keypad contacts. This was confirmed upon opening the keypad assembly, revealing dull key contacts. The contact pads were unsoldered and removed for a closer look. While they seemed okay, the leaf contacts engaged by the actuators showed signs of oxidation. To address the oxidation, a fiberglass brush and Deoxit were used, restoring the contacts to a shiny and clean condition.

item.title: Beogram 4002: From Oil Cleanup to First Operational Test
item.description: The Beogram 4002 restoration hit a snag. Although the main board was restored, the presence of rust and corrosion discovered earlier took priority. Addressing rust requires applying neutralizer and paint, which involves drying time between coats, thus delaying the planned reservoir capacitor and output board work. Images highlighting the most severe rust spots are included. Despite the significant rust, the turntable’s overall condition is good. To combat the rust, three coats of rust neutralizer were applied.

item.title: Beogram 4002: Final Tasks, Adjustments & Playing Records
item.description: The final steps of a Beogram 4002 Type 5513 restoration project involved addressing corrosion damage and replacing the 5-pin DIN phono plug. Using a helpful audio path diagram, continuity checks were performed from the cartridge connector to ensure proper signal flow. The replacement phono plug, a REAN model with gold contact pins, was installed, though the tight fit of the rubber boot on the cable posed a minor challenge. As an improvement, a grounding switch was added to the output board, eliminating the need for an external grounding wire.

item.title: Beogram 4002 Type 5513: Beogram 4002 Bonanza!
item.description: We seem to be inundated with Beogram 400x turntable restorations. Beolover is occupied with multiple projects, and I have two Beogram 4002 Type 5513 projects that I began examining back in February of 2020. In those previous posts, I had sent four Beogram 400x platter motors to Beolover for his restoration expertise. He has since completed those motors, and they are now back in my possession, ready to be used.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Tangential Arm Assembly Oil Cleanup and Restoration
item.description: This Beogram 4002 restoration project continued with a thorough cleaning of the cabinet’s interior, focusing on removing oil residue. The tangential arm assembly was detached to access and clean the oil contamination found throughout the unit. The oil had spread extensively, affecting various components from the arm’s mechanics to the switch contacts. The tangential arm position sensor assembly was entirely disassembled for cleaning. With the old oil removed, the arm assembly restoration and adjustments could begin.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Second Unit From Houston
item.description: A few weeks back, I completed the first of two Beogram 4002 (Type 5513) turntable restorations for a client in Houston. I’m now starting work on the second one. Both turntable platters had their motors removed before being sent to Beolover for refurbishment. He has since finished these and documented the process on his blog. I believe that refurbishing the platter motor is an essential step in any Beogram 400x restoration project.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Floating Suspension, Reservoir Capacitor & Platter Motor
item.description: This project is nearing completion. This post details the remounting of the floating chassis within the cabinet, replacing the reservoir capacitor, and installing the refurbished platter motor. Here are the parts needed for mounting the floating suspension system back into the cabinet. The threaded pin’s longer section is positioned at the bottom. When attaching the wing-nut, ensure it sits at the very beginning of the thread. I personally position it to allow enough thread for securing the nut while keeping the nut’s outer edge aligned with the topmost thread.

item.title: Beogram 4002 Type 5513: Floating Chassis
item.description: This short post will illustrate an intriguing difference in the suspension systems of two Beogram 4002 Type 5513 turntables. The first Beogram 4002 Type 5513, serial number 1312615, used a stack of concave washers to secure the floating suspension to the top plate. These washers were also present on the bottom lock. The second Beogram 4002 Type 5513, serial number 1311076, features a slightly different suspension mechanism. This earlier production model employs a single, concave metal piece between the suspension lock and the top plate.

item.title: Beogram 4002 Type 5513: Inside Work
item.description: My work on restoring a Beogram 4002 turntable from Houston continues, focusing on the internal components this time. This update covers the refurbishment of the tangential arm assembly and the replacement of the Beogram’s reservoir capacitor. Here’s a current picture of the Beogram 4002 with its chassis and tangential arm assembly removed. The tangential arm assembly components on this Beogram 4002 are in great condition. My work mainly involved cleaning and lubricating the Beogram chassis parts.

item.title: Beogram 4002 Type 5513: Houston Beogram #3 Ready for Action Again
item.description: My favorite stage of the Beogram 4002 restoration is here. The only remaining tasks are some enjoyable record-playing tests in my office. I find listening to records through a favorite system while working far more pleasurable than watching television…and it’s a necessary job that someone has to do. I’m truly happy with how this Beogram turned out. Knowing this turntable has been meticulously serviced is a great feeling. It’s spotless inside, and Beolover did an exceptional job revitalizing the platter motor.

item.title: Beogram 4002 Type 5513: Adjusting/Calibrating the Detector Arm Circuit
item.description: The Beogram 4002 turntable is nearly ready for use, with most of the necessary adjustments and calibrations finalized. As planned, the record detection circuit needed adjustment due to a low measurement. Utilizing insights from Beolover’s blog post on the Beogram 4002 record detection circuit, the circuit was calibrated to align with the service manual’s specifications. Two components on the main board, 1R26 (a 1MΩ resistor) and 1TR3 (an NPN BC548C transistor), are key in fine-tuning the signal from the record detection circuit.

item.title: Beogram 4002 Type 5513: Initial Assessment
item.description: A Beogram 4002 turntable, dropped off by its long-time owner, appears to have been well-maintained. The control panel buttons show typical wear from use, but the dust cover is in good condition with only minor marks. The tonearm requires adjustment as it sits too low when the turntable is not in use. The turntable’s interior is very clean, suggesting it was kept in a good environment. The original washers for the floating suspension lock-down are intact.

item.title: Beogram 4002 Type 5513: Reinstalling the Floating Chassis Components
item.description: All the necessary restoration parts for the Beogram 4002 (Type 5513) turntable are now available, marking the start of the reassembly process. The reinstallation begins with securing the floating chassis, equipped with the tangential arm assembly, back into the Beogram 4002 cabinet. The process starts by fitting the Beolover replacement suspension lock bushings onto the floating chassis. Subsequently, the suspension locks are positioned within the cabinet base. The floating chassis is then carefully lowered onto these locking bolts, and the remaining locking mechanisms are put in place.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Electrical Work and Initial Tracking Adjustment
item.description: Let’s begin restoring the electronic boards. The main control board needs its capacitors replaced and the RPM relay (along with the RPM trimmers) need attention. Additionally, the output board requires inspection of its phono muting circuit. It’s worth noting that aside from wiring, the muting relay is the sole electrical part interacting with the phono audio signal. The turntable’s electronics mainly manage the platter motor, tangential arm, indicator lamps, and user controls, none of which are part of the audio pathway.

item.title: Beogram 4002 Type 5513: Reassembly of the Floating Chassis and Some Initial Checks
item.description: After completing the tangential arm assembly checks and cleaning the Beogram 4002 cabinet, it was time to reinstall the floating chassis. The reassembly began with cleaning and lubricating the three suspension lock down screws, then reinstalling them in the Beogram cabinet. With all three suspension locks back in place, the platter motor and output board, which had been previously restored, were reinstalled. The control panel, RPM indicator panel, and arm position scale were then put back in their respective places.

item.title: Beogram 4002 Type 5513: Service Manual Checks and Sensor Adjustment for the Third Beogram from Houston
item.description: The Beogram 4002 restoration is nearing completion, moving from the workbench to the test bench. The final phase involved service manual checks and adjustments, along with calibrating the record detection, arm position, and tracking sensors. Following a guide, the record detection sensor was calibrated by adjusting the 1TR3 collector voltage to 4 VDC for an empty, spinning platter. This voltage should remain consistent with a record on the platter. Next, the tangential arm position sensor was adjusted to achieve 5 VDC at the 4IC1 collector when illuminated by the sensor lamp through a transparent part of the position scale.

item.title: Beogram 4002 Type 5513: Some additions for a previous Beogram project from Houston
item.description: A Beogram 4002 Type 5513 turntable I previously restored in 2018 was returned for a sensor lamp replacement. This turntable had also visited in 2020 for a broken tonearm cartridge mount. During both prior repairs, the owner opted to retain some original, functioning components, including the sensor lamp, tracking sensor lamp, and output phono muting switch. Since the sensor lamp has now burned out, it will be replaced with a modern Beolover LED assembly.

item.title: Beogram 4002: New Project From Houston
item.description: My next project takes me away from Beomaster restorations and back to Beogram turntables. It’s great to work on both, so I’m excited regardless. A gentleman from Houston entrusted me with two Beogram 4002 Type 5513 turntables he acquired some years ago. As time took its toll, they stopped functioning properly. Like many Beogram 4002 owners, he realized he missed listening to his vinyl records and decided to have them restored.

item.title: Beogram 4002 Type 5513: Recapping the main controller board and the output board
item.description: The main controller and output boards have had their capacitors successfully replaced. In addition to replacing the electrolytic and tantalum capacitors on the main controller board, the RPM selection relay and both RPM adjustment trimmers were also replaced. [Image of speed components on the main controller board] This image highlights two components within the main controller board’s record detection circuit that might require further attention and modification. A determination on whether these components need changing will be made after evaluating all the Beogram 4002 photo sensors.

item.title: Beogram 4002 Type 5513: Installing Beolover RPM Indicators, Rechecking Platter Speed, Beginning the Reassembly
item.description: I replaced the RPM indicator lamps in my Beogram 400x turntable with LED modules from Beolover. This upgrade, motivated by the LEDs’ stability rather than longevity, aims to enhance platter motor speed stability, a known benefit observed in Beolover’s motor restorations. The interconnectedness of the RPM lamps and the platter motor circuit underscores their impact on performance. The original incandescent lamps were removed from the Beogram 4002 Type 5513 RPM Indicator Panel and replaced with the Beolover LED modules, which were secured and insulated using the provided double-sided mounting tape.

item.title: Beogram 4002 Type 5513: Going over the chassis and mechanical parts
item.description: The two circuit boards that needed component updates are finished. Now, I’m focusing on the Beogram 4002’s cabinet and its mechanical parts. I prefer working on the floating chassis with it removed, which is easier since I’ll disassemble most of the tangential arm. This revealed some hidden issues. Initially, I believed the three chassis lock bushings were okay because they looked fine. However, examining the locking mechanism showed otherwise. This was the first indication of the bushings’ poor condition.

item.title: Beogram 4002 Type 5513: Going Through the Service Manual Checks and Adjustments
item.description: This past weekend, I began working on some of the checks and adjustments outlined in the Beogram 4002 service manual. The manual details both electrical and mechanical procedures. On the electrical side, my primary focus is to ensure that the photo sensors generate strong signals when activated by their light sources. Maintaining correct voltages is crucial for the proper function of the Beogram 4002’s analog control system. Mechanically, I’ll be aligning both the Beogram’s fixed arm and tonearm.
